bestBHT.bht: In response to the accusation of associating with uncircumcised men, Peter brings up the six brethren who had witnessed the events firsthand. Notably, he avoids mentioning Cornelius' name or high position, instead emphasizing the uncircumcised man to whom he had been divinely sent. Peter acknowledges the charge against him and any potential doubt, but affirms that it was the Spirit who commanded him to go with them. This revelation suggests that Peter was aware of the scrutiny he would face for his actions.

Henry Alford: 12. these six brethren] They had accompanied him to Jerusalem, and were there to substantiate the facts, as far as they had witnessed them.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: No mention of Cornelius' name, much less of his high position, as if that affected the question.
To the charge, 'Thou wentest in to men uncircumcised,' he simply speaks of the uncircumcised 'man' to whom he had been divinely sent.
Marvin Vincent: Nothing doubting [μηδεν διακρινομενον]. The Rev. renders making no distinction, taking the verb in its original sense, which is to separate or distinguish. The rendering seems rather strained, doubting being a common rendering in the New Testament and giving a perfectly good sense here."

The six brethren. The men of Joppa who had gone with Peter to Cornelius, and had accompanied him also to Jerusalem, either as witnesses for him or for their own vindication, since they had committed the same offense.
Philip Schaff: St. Peter had said nothing of having gone up to the house-top.
The phrase 'these six brethren,' marking the vividness of his appeal to them at the moment of speaking, should not be unobserved.

Even as regards the personal character of Cornelius, his habit of prayer, his generous almsgiving, his faithful discharge of domestic duty, it would not have been politic in Peter to have laid stress on these points before an audience full of prejudice against the Heathen.
Archibald T. Robertson: Making no distinction... The difference in voice shows the distinction in meaning.
We entered into the man's house... Peter confesses it, but shows that the other six went in also.
He avoids mention of Cornelius's name and office.
John Gill: And the Spirit bade me go with them, nothing doubting
it looks as if Peter was aware, that he should be called to an account for his conduct
entering into whose house they were contending with him

bhtAttempts.bht: Peter is addressing the accusation of his association with uncircumcised men, and he does so by referencing the six brethren who had witnessed his interaction with Cornelius. Peter intentionally avoids mentioning Cornelius' name and high position, focusing instead on the uncircumcised man to whom he had been divinely sent. By stating that they all entered into the man's house, Peter emphasizes that it was not only him but also the other six brethren who were involved. He acknowledges the charge against him and acknowledges any potential doubt, but clarifies that the Spirit had commanded him to go with them. This revelation indicates that Peter was aware that his actions would be scrutinized.

Peter, in response to the accusation of associating with uncircumcised men, defends himself by referencing the six brethren who were witnesses to his interaction with the uncircumcised man. He avoids mentioning Cornelius' name and position, instead emphasizing the divine direction he received to go to the uncircumcised. Peter acknowledges the charge against him and any potential doubt, but clarifies that he was commanded by the Spirit to go with them, showing his awareness of the scrutiny his actions would face.

Peter defends himself against the accusation of associating with uncircumcised men by referring to the six brethren who witnessed his encounter with the uncircumcised man. He intentionally avoids mentioning Cornelius' name and position, focusing instead on the divine command that led him to the uncircumcised. Peter acknowledges the charge and any possible doubt, but clarifies that the Spirit instructed him to go with them, indicating his awareness of the scrutiny his actions would face.

In response to the accusation of associating with uncircumcised men, Peter brings up the six brethren who had witnessed the events firsthand. Notably, he avoids mentioning Cornelius' name or high position, instead emphasizing the uncircumcised man to whom he had been divinely sent. Peter acknowledges the charge against him and any potential doubt, but affirms that it was the Spirit who commanded him to go with them. This revelation suggests that Peter was aware of the scrutiny he would face for his actions.

In response to the accusation of associating with uncircumcised men, Peter points to the six brethren who had accompanied him as witnesses. He deliberately avoids mentioning Cornelius' name and position, focusing instead on the uncircumcised man he had been sent to by divine guidance. Peter acknowledges the charge and any doubt, but asserts that the Spirit commanded him to go with them. This indicates Peter's awareness that his actions would be scrutinized and calls into question the validity of the accusation.
